Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogenomics and biogeography of Vochysia, unraveling its tempo and mode of evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most intriguing questions in modern biogeography relates to Neotropical plant diversity. The high number of species in this region was once thought to be due to the antiquity of rainforest habitats; however, recent studies suggest that many Neotropical flowering plant groups have been diversifying in the last 10-20 my. Recent episodes of plant diversification in the neotropics raise questions such as why have there been so many recent speciation events and what were the contributing biotic and abiotic factors. This study aims to investigate the biogeography and origin of Vochysia, a strictly Neotropical group that is hyper-diverse, widely distributed and relatively young. By contributing to a better understanding about the drivers of recent diversification in a group of plants, it will lead to an improvement in general conservation strategies since it will improve knowledge about species distribution and diversification. This research will be valuable for the academic progress of a graduate student and an undergraduate student that is gaining experience in bioinformatics, data analysis, laboratory, and herbarium protocols.

This project seeks to improve the knowledge of the historical biogeography of plants of the neotropics by investigating the tempo and mode of Vochysia diversification. A phylogenetic reconstruction of the group will be done using next generation sequencing and computational analytical tools to provide a phylogenetic tree for investigating the evolutionary history of Vochysia. The analysis of the mode of evolution will be done using software for phylogenetic tree dating calibration, biogeographical reconstruction, and niche modeling. Results from these analyses will allow inferences to be made about the relative importance of vicariance versus dispersal and niche conservatism versus divergence with an emphasis on endemic and rare species of Vochysia. The tempo of Vochysia diversification will involve comparing the net diversification rates within the genus and between sub-clades from different biomes using a modern Bayesian-based software that models the complex dynamics of species diversification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most intriguing questions in modern biogeography relates to Neotropical plant diversity. The high number of species in this region was once thought to be due to the antiquity of rainforest habitats, whereas other studies suggest high rates of speciation and extinction occurred through its history with many flowering plants groups diversifying in the last 10-20 million years. These episodes of plant diversification in the neotropics raise questions such as why were there so many recent speciation events and what were the biotic and abiotic factors that may have had effects on plant diversification. In order to better understand Neotropical plant evolution, studies are being developed for plant groups that occur primarily in the neotropics. This study aimed to investigate the evolutionary history of a strictly Neotropical group that is widely distributed and relatively young. Using new approaches, we explored interesting questions about the biogeography and origin of the Neotropical plant hyperdiversity. A better understanding about the drivers of recent diversification generate information to aid the design of more efficient conservation strategies. Developing this project was also valuable for the academic experience and progress of the graduate student co-PI (DJPG) and to an undergraduate student (Brooke Bowman) that gained experience in bioinformatics, data analysis, laboratory, and herbarium protocols. 

Vochysia (ca. 140 spp.) has a wide range of geographic distribution in Neotropical lowlands and is the most diverse genus of Vochysiaceae (ca. 250 spp.). This project sought to improve the knowledge of the historical biogeography of plants of the neotropics using Vochysia as a model system. In order to generate a well resolved, dated phylogeny to explore the biogeography and drivers of diversification, first there was the need to gather the data and explore the systematics of Vochysiaceae. Thus, the specific objectives of this project were to increase sampling of Vochysia, gathering molecular data and also data about habitat and geographic distribution. Since the placement of Vochysiaceae within Myrtales, the order that the family is currently circumscribed, and the intra-familiar relationships of Vochysiaceae were based on a few species and markers, these relationships were also verified.

            After completing all DNA isolations, sequencing and data processing, three matrices representing the three genomic compartments present in plant cells were generated to produce a taxon- and molecular-dense phylogeny. The first matrix encompasses 78 plastid protein coding genes of 234 species (152 newly sequenced samples, 82 samples from NCBI) of which 109 samples represent species of Vochysia. The second and third matrices are composed of 36 genes from the mitochondrial genome and the nuclear ribosomal cistron (26S, 5.8S, 18S, ITS1, ITS2). These last two matrices have information of 152 samples. Three species from other orders of angiosperms were included in the three matrices to serve as outgroups. 

Phylogenies reconstructed under different frameworks of phylogenetic inference (Maximum Likelihood and Multispecies Coalescent Method) supported the current classification of Vochysiaceae as sister to Myrtaceae. Within Vochysiaceae, the current classification of its tribes was not supported. Instead, a Neotropical and an African clade were recovered, not supporting the classification of Erismeae, composed with one genus from the Neotropics and two genera from the Old World. The infrageneric classification of Callisthene, Qualea, and the infrageneric relationships of both genera were recovered as monophyletic following the current classification of the family. On the other hand, the genus Ruizteraniawas recovered within Qualea, not supporting the current classification of both genera. The backbone phylogeny of Vochysia frequently did not support the infrageneric classification in which monophyly of subgeneric taxa was prevented due to one or a few species appearing in different groups.  For example, Vochysia sect. Vochysiella subsect. Decorticantes appeared monophyletic with the exception of V. divergens that nested with some species of V. sect. Vochysiella subsect. Calophylloideae. Also, V. pseudopumila (V. sect. Ciliantha subsect. Micranthae) and V. neyratii (position not indicated in the protologue) nested within V. sect.Vochysiella subsect. Decorticantes.

Now that sampling is completed and phylogenetic analyses are in advanced stages, analyses of divergence time estimations, biogeographical reconstructions, and tempo of species diversification are in progress. Results from these analyses will provide estimates about the time of divergence between the Neotropical and the African clades of Vochysiaceae. Historical biogeography approach will allow an assessment of the relative importance of vicariance versus dispersal and niche conservatism versus divergence. Overall, the completion of this project will provide an interpretation of patterns of evolution at a continental scale, possibly contributing to the development of more effective conservation strategies in the Amazon and other highly threatened biomes (e.g., the Brazilian savannas).
